title: PhD on Particle-stabilized Pickering Emulsions in Droplet-based Microfluidic Environments to Mimic Biomimetic Erythrocyte (Red Blood Cell) Membranes
field: Analytical Chemistry, Bioengineering, Chemical Engineering, Inorganic Chemistry, Materials Chemistry, and 4 moreMaterials Engineering,Nanochemistry,Nanotechnology,Particle Physics

BAP-2022-92)This PhD position is with Prof. Erin Koos (Soft Matter, Rheology and Technology section of the Department of Chemical Engineering, https://cit.kuleuven.be/smart/) and Xevi Casadevall i Solvas (Mechatronics, Biostatistics and Sensors section of the Department of Biosystems, https://www.biw.kuleuven.be/biosyst/mebios). The PhD research will be conducted in the framework of the EIC Pathfinder program SynEry.Website unitProjectBlood is a precious and vital resource for many clinical interventions. Erythrocytes (red blood cells), one of its key components, are used to save thousands of lives every day worldwide. Yet, in low- and middle-income countries, insufficient blood donations and their unsafe control are endemic burdens that cost lives. Despite several decades of attempts a safe and universal blood substitute has yet to be developed. The ambitious goal of the SynEry project (funded via an EICPathfinder Open framework of Horizon Europe) is to reproduce key features of erythrocytes in an advanced lipid vesicle or synthetic erythrocyte. Specifically, this position aims to develop particle-stabilized Pickering emulsions in droplet-based microfluidic environments in order to assist the reconstruction of biomimetic erythrocyte membranes. The knowledge gained by producing such a synthetic erythrocyte, is envisioned to enable the production of artificial cells with in-vivo applicability and it will pave the way towards the future development of an effective blood substitute that can remedy pervasive global blood availability and safety issues.Key tasks:Synthesizing and characterizing inorganic nanoparticles for production of Pickering emulsions with different functional groups.Characterization of the nanoparticles self-assembly processes and their spatial distribution at the interface of water-in-oil microdroplets.Characterize the mechanical properties of the Pickering emulsions using a combination of imaging techniques (e.g. confocal microscopy and SEM) and rheology with a focus on the resistance of the droplet breakup and coalescence in flow.Developing strategies to tune the physical properties of Pickering emulsions leading to either increased or decreased stability of the particle-stabilized interface.ProfileAre you an energetic person, able to both think critically and creatively in scientific terms while also being effective at resolving technical challenges? Are you keen on working at the crossroads of several disciplines (from chemical engineering to biomedicine)?
